repnme.cdata!:
Lao, Democratic Republic of - Poverty
            Reduction Fund Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Poverty Reduction Fund
            Project for Lao, Democratic Republic of were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory and
            borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: poverty targeting requires clearly
            defined frameworks and monitoring. The initial problems and
            the time taken to identify and resolve the poverty targeting
            approach suggest that future operations will benefit from
            clearer design targets, stronger indicators, improved
            assessment and closer monitoring. The lesson from the Lao
            experience is that this trade off can be justified given the
            specific poverty reduction objectives, the intention to
            reach villages in remote mountainous regions and the need to
            'protect' the participatory and multi-sector
            demand-driven approach-all of which would likely have been
            compromised if the project had been delivered through
            centralized, top-down line departments without the
            experience, capacity for outreach or commitment to innovate.
            More rigorous qualitative analysis and experimental
            fieldwork, especially in relation to voice and engagement,
            and capacity building should be conducted as the project
            proceeds, with far increased budgets and efforts to appoint
            skilled consultants that have a track record elsewhere.

repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Poverty Reduction Fund

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about Poverty
            Reduction Fund (PRF) in Lao People's Democratic
            Republic. Lao is trying to graduate from least-developed
            country status and join the ranks of middle-income countries
            by 2020. But in a country that includes more than 47
            different ethnic groups and in which 70 percent of people
            live on less than 2 dollars a day, particularly in remote
            rural areas, poverty alleviation programs needed to put
            local people in the driver’s seat to make headway. PRF
            empowered the poor, women and ethnic minorities in rural
            villages to assess their own needs and priorities, and built
            capacity for them to plan, built and managed local
            infrastructure in a decentralized and transparent manner.
            The priorities based on community requests were safe water
            supply, access roads, primary schools, health clinics,
            irrigation systems and village markets. As a result, more
            than 900 villages have access to clean water, 460 schools
            and 40 health clinics have been built in remote villages,
            2,000 kilometers of rural access roads have been upgraded,
            70 bridges have been built, and 1,900 training sessions in
            infrastructure maintenance and usage and vocational skills
            were provided to participating villagers

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Poverty Reduction Fund Project :
            additional financing

abstracts.cdata!:
The Lao People's Democratic
            Republic for the Poverty Reduction Fund Project (PRFP)
            additional financing will support the project scale up and
            restructuring in the form of a 3 year extension of
            activities of the PRFP in the 14 poorest districts it
            already covers (out of 21 currently covered), initiate
            activities in 5 new poor districts, and add a new
            sub-component, "Capacity Building of Local
            Institutions", intended to promote participatory
            planning by enhancing the dialogue between communities and
            local governments. The village targeting mechanism and key
            performance indicators will also be modified to strengthen
            the pro-poor focus of the PRFP. In the additional financing
            phase, the project will continue supporting the development
            of local infrastructure and communities' empowerment in
            the poorest districts. The PRFP already underwent five
            annual investment cycles financed by the original
            International Development Association (IDA) credit, and
            under the additional phase (cycles VI to VIII) for the
            period up to September 2011, funds will be devoted to more
            than 1,500 sub-projects covering 19 "first
            priority" districts (of which 5 are new), 1,640
            villages, and 593,798 people. In all these villages, the
            PRFP will also support community and local government
            empowerment activities.
